channel.title: BBC News - Business

item.title: House prices at new high but pace of growth slows
item.description: Prices are rising slowly in London, but more rapidly in Wales and south-west England, the Halifax says.

item.title: Planned job cuts fall despite furlough deadline
item.description: August saw the fewest redundancies since 2014 despite plans to end furlough on 30 September.

item.title: UK fires up coal power plant as gas prices soar
item.description: The country has had to bring an old plant back online after a spike in the price of natural gas.

item.title: Fear and excitement in El Salvador as Bitcoin becomes legal tender
item.description: Millions of Salvadorians are expected to download a digital wallet app with $30 of free Bitcoin.

item.title: Chip shortage could last into 2023, says car boss
item.description: The car industry must learn from the Covid "stress test", says Mercedes-Benz-owner Daimler.

item.title: 'A hotel without linen is not a hotel'
item.description: The laundry firms that provide bed linen for hotels across the UK are facing an unprecedented crisis.

item.title: Kim Kardashian crypto ad singled out by financial watchdog
item.description: An Instagram ad by the influencer was criticised in a speech by FCA chairman Charles Randell.

item.title: 'Young, black people have to work three times as hard'
item.description: This week sees the launch of a programme making high-flying careers more accessible.

item.title: Pensions: What is the triple lock and how does it work?
item.description: Speculation is mounting that the chancellor will change the policy governing state pension rises, but why?

item.title: M&S warns of new food supplies threat as Brexit rules change
item.description: Retailer warns of "significant disruption" to food imports when new paperwork comes in next month.

item.title: Staff shortages could last two years, says CBI
item.description: Industry body the CBI wants immigration rules eased for lorry drivers, welders, butchers and bricklayers.

item.title: Social care: What would a National Insurance rise mean for me?
item.description: The government could raise National Insurance to help pay for social care in England.

item.title: Cash incentives on student accounts squeezed
item.description: Upfront sums for opening an account are less generous than previous years, analysis shows.

item.title: Black interns: 'You just need to give us a chance'
item.description: Young black university students are being invited to apply for 2,000 internships at top companies.

item.title: England sees 'boom' in second homes flipped to holiday lets
item.description: More than 11,000 second homes become rental businesses since the pandemic began, research shows.

item.title: When is a motor show not a motor show?
item.description: Germany's International Motor Show has become a mobility exhibition, says the BBC's Theo Leggett

item.title: Ikea struggles with supply problems due to driver shortage
item.description: The furniture giant is among businesses struggling with a driver shortage due to Covid and Brexit.

item.title: Has Covid killed off business cards for good?
item.description: Sales of business cards have fallen sharply as a result of the pandemic.

item.title: 'Bitcoin fraud cost me Â£500,000'
item.description: A successful businessman saw his life savings wiped out when he fell victim to ruthless fraudsters.

item.title: Why picking a good company name is a tricky business
item.description: With the number of new start-ups soaring they all have to choose a name for themselves.

item.title: CEO Secrets: 'I was making money, but had no money'
item.description: Honey boss Scott Davies says cash flow problems meant though he was profitable he "had no money".

item.title: Can apps move the #MeToo movement forward?
item.description: Reporting sexual harassment at work is getting easier thanks to new technologies.

item.title: Japan's huge army of under-employed ex-housewives
item.description: Why women are still battling for better jobs in the world's third largest economy.

item.title: The pubs and restaurants counting on Christmas cheer
item.description: In a bid to rebound from Covid plans for this year's festive season are under way.

item.title: CEO Secrets: 'Tear up the business plan'
item.description: CEO Secrets: Brooklyn Brewery boss Eric Ottaway says - be ready to ditch your business plan.
